revision.text:
[[File:UC Solar Team Logo.jpg|thumb|300px|right|University of Calgary Solar Team Logo]] The '''University of Calgary Solar Car Team''' is a multi-disciplinary student-run [[solar car racing]] ("raycing") team at the [[University of Calgary]], based in [[Calgary]], [[Alberta]], [[Canada]]. It was established to design and build a solar car to compete in the [[American Solar Challenge]] (ASC) (previously named the North American Solar Challenge) and the [[World Solar Challenge]] (WSC). The team is primarily composed of undergraduate students studying Engineering, Business, Science, Arts and Kinesiology. The mission of the University of Calgary Solar Car Team is to educate the community about sustainable energy and to serve as an interdisciplinary project through which students and faculty from various departments can collaborate in supporting sustainable energy. == History == The University of Calgary Solar Car Team was established in the fall of 2004. The team was created to build a solar powered vehicle to complete in the 2005 North American Solar Challenge. [[Image:UCSolarX1-StampedeParade-Wikipedia.jpg|thumb|400px|right|This is an image of the X1, the prototype solar car created by the UC Solar team for testing purposes. In this image it is being piloted by driver James Snell for the [[Calgary Stampede Parade]] in the summer of 2005.]] ==Soleon== ===Miracle workers=== The team performed a "miracle" by managing to establish a strong student base with which to construct the car, procure significant sponsorship and successfully build a highly successful vehicle with limited experience all in approximately 9 months. Established teams have two years to refine existing designs between [[Solar car racing|rayces]]. === The X1 (prototype) === In preparation for its first rayce, the University of Calgary Solar Team constructed and tested a prototype of their designs before building the final car. The X1 was a mock-up of and predecessor to Soleon. The X1 was used for driver training and allowed the team to test various design decisions to help ensure a successful final product. The X1 was constructed from a steel chassis with a [[fibreglass]] shell which was coated with [[gelcoat]] which made the vehicle approximately twice the final weight of its sister car. === First race results === In its first year of existence the University of Calgary Solar Team successfully competed in the NASC and the WSC. In the 2005 NASC, Soleon, their first generation rayce car placed 13th out of 17 cars that made it to the finish line. In the 2005 WSC Soleon placed 10th overall (out of 18) and first in its class. After hearing about this success, [[Seymour Schulich]] was inspired to donate $25 million (another $25 million was matched by the Alberta government) to the University of Calgary Engineering department, which was renamed the [[Schulich School of Engineering]]. ==Schulich I== === 2007 WSC race === Since the success of Soleon in the 2005 races, the team had to redesign for the new regulations for WSC, and prepare for the harder competition it faced from changing class to the higher, more competitive Challenge class. This class included higher efficiency [[solar cell]]s, upright seating, and teams that had been raycing for the last 20 years. After shipping their new car to Australia, and testing it before scrutineering, the car had a rear tire blow out on the race track in [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]], and resulted in the car spinning around having the tail section impacting into the guard rail and ripped from the car. The team then had to rebuild and redesign the tail section in one night before racing. Despite the higher competition and race track crash, the team managed to be the first (of six) Canadian teams to cross the timing finish line, finish 8th (out of 19) in the Challenge class, and 15th (out of 37) overall. === 2008 NASC race === Schulich I was improved after WSC 2007 for racing in the 2008 North American Solar Challenge. The rayce from Dallas, Texas to Calgary lasted ten days, with the University of Calgary Solar Team placing 6th (out of 15). ==Schulich Axiom== === 2010 ASC === The University of Calgary's 3rd generation car, Schulich Axiom, was first raced in the 2010 ASC. The race spanned 1770 km from Tulsa, Oklahoma to Chicago, Illinois. The team finished in 6th place (of 18 teams) and received both the Sportsmanship and Mechanical Engineering awards for the race. With regulation changes for the 2011 WSC, the team re-engineered the design of Schulich Axiom and completely rebuilt the solar car. Some of the changes made include switching to silicon solar cells and reducing the weight of the car.The car was unveiled November 2009 to a sold out crowd at the Fairmont Palliser Hotel in Calgary, Alberta. === 2011 WSC === The 2011 WSC takes place October 16–23, 2011 and runs from Darwin, Northern Territory to Adelaide, South Australia. The University of Calgary Solar Team has entered Schulich Axiom in the race. == Achievements == {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#CCCCCC;" ! Year!! Vehicle !! Achievements |- | 2005 || Soleon || 1st Place Stock Class WSC 2005 |- | || || 10th Place Overall WSC 2005 |- | || || 13th Place Overall NASC 2005 |- | || || Top Canadian Team at WSC 2005 |- | || || Best Rookie Team, Teamwork and Esprit de Corps Awards at NASC 2005 |- | 2007 || Schulich I || First of six Canadian teams to cross timing finish line |- | || || 8th Place in Challenge Class WSC 2007 |- | || || 15th Place Overall WSC 2007 |- | 2008 || Schulich I || 6th Place Overall NASC 2008 |- | 2010 || Schulich Axiom || 6th Place Overall ASC 2010 |- | || || Award for Mechanical Engineering Excellence ASC 2010 |- | || || Award for Sportsmanship ASC 2010 (Shared with two other teams) |} ==Schulich Delta== === Design and construction === Schulich Delta was designed over the course of eight months, and construction took another three months. Delta was a radical departure for the team, featuring two doors, four wheels, a passenger seat and cargo space for the very first time. === 2013 WSC === The team has entered Schulich Delta to compete in the Cruiser class in the 2013 World Solar Challenge from October 6–13, 2013. == Cars == [[Image:UCSolar-X1-Wikipedia.JPG|thumb|400px|left]] ===X1 (prototype)=== '''Maximum Achieved Speed:''' ~70 km/h
'''Solar Array Type:''' none (stickers merely for show)
'''Chassis:''' Steel [[Space frame]]
'''Shell Composition:''' [[Fibreglass]] & [[Gelcoat]]
'''Commissioned:''' May 2005
'''Decommissioned:''' June 2006
'''Current Uses:''' X1 has been decommissioned. The chassis is all that remains. It is suspended against a wall in the University of Calgary Solar Team's workshop. [[Image:Soleon on day 2 of NASC 05.jpg|thumb|400px|left]] ===Soleon=== '''Maximum Achieved Speed:''' 140 km/h
'''Solar Array Type:''' Silicon
'''Chassis:''' Aluminum [[Space frame]]
'''Shell Composition:''' [[Carbon Fiber]] & [[Kevlar]]
'''Weight:''' ~500 lbs
'''Commissioned:''' June 2005
'''Decommissioned:''' July 2007
'''Current Uses:''' In the fall of 2008 Soleon was donated to the [[Telus World of Science, Calgary|Calgary Telus World of Science]] and was on display for 2 years. Soleon is now retired and looking for a nice warm garage to rest. [[Image:UC Solar Team with Schulich.JPG|thumb|400px|left]] ===Schulich I=== '''Maximum Achieved Speed:''' 105 km/h
'''Solar Array Type:''' [[Gallium arsenide]] (GaAs) Triple-junction
'''Chassis:''' Steel [[Space frame]]
'''Shell Composition:''' [[Carbon Fiber]] & [[Kevlar]]
'''Weight:''' ~520 lbs
'''Commissioned:''' September 2007
'''Decommissioned:''' May 2011
'''Current Uses:''' Participated in the 2007 [[Panasonic World Solar Challenge]] and the 2008 [[North American Solar Challenge]]. Since Axiom is now being used for driver training, mechanical testing and PR events, Schulich I has been retired. [[File:AxiomStartLine.jpg|thumb|400px|left]] ===Schulich Axiom (2010)=== '''Maximum Achieved Speed:''' 130 km/h
'''Solar Array Type:''' [[Gallium arsenide]] (GaAs) Triple-junction
'''Chassis:''' [[Carbon Fiber]] & [[Kevlar]]
'''Shell Composition:''' [[Carbon Fiber]] & [[Kevlar]]
'''Weight:''' ~600 lbs
'''Commissioned:''' October 2009
'''Current Uses:''' Placed 6th overall in the 2010 [[North American Solar Challenge]]. Schulich Axiom (2010) is now predominantly being used as a display vehicle. [[File:AxiomLight.jpg|thumb|400px|left]] ===Schulich Axiom (2011)=== '''Maximum Achieved Speed:''' 110 km/h
'''Solar Array Type:''' Silicon Monocrystalline (Si) UC Solar Embedded
'''Chassis:''' [[Carbon Fiber]]
'''Shell Composition:''' [[Carbon Fiber]]
'''Weight:''' ~390 lbs
'''Commissioned:''' May 2011
'''Current Uses:''' Planning on racing in the 2011 [[World Solar Challenge]]. All improvements have since been completed to Schulich Axiom. "It is evident from the previous race that weight is no minor detail. We have taken Axiom on its diet and the result is stunning. Axiom has dropped from around 600 lbs. without driver and ballast to 390 lbs. A loss of 210 lbs!" -Mico Madamesila
== References == {{reflist}} {{refbegin}} * https://www.ucalgary.ca/news/utoday/november23-09/solarcar * http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/SciTech/20091123/solar_car_091123/{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{refend}} ==External links== {{Portal|Renewable energy|Energy}} * [http://www.calgarysolarcar.ca Official Team Website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090301150617/http://www.wsc.org.au/ WSC Website] * [http://www.americansolarchallenge.org NASC Website] {{University of Calgary}} {{Photovoltaics}} [[Category:University of Calgary]] [[Category:Solar car racing]] [[Category:Photovoltaics]]

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=December 2011}} {{more footnotes|date=December 2011}} }} The '''TORRO tornado intensity scale''' (or '''T-Scale''') is a scale measuring [[tornado]] intensity between T0 and T11. It was proposed by Terence Meaden of the [[Tornado and Storm Research Organisation (TORRO)]], a [[meteorology|meteorological]] organisation in the [[United Kingdom]], as an extension of the [[Beaufort scale]]. == History and derivation from Beaufort scale == The scale was tested from 1972 to 1975 and was made public at a meeting of the [[Royal Meteorological Society]] in 1975. The scale sets T0 as the equivalent of 8 on the Beaufort scale and is related to the Beaufort scale (B) by the formula: : ''B'' = 2 (''T'' + 4) and conversely: : ''T'' = (''B''/2 - 4) {| class="wikitable" |- |style="background: #E0E0FF"| ''Beaufort scale'' |style="background: #E0E0FF"| '''B''' |width="20" style="text-align:right"| 8 |width="20" style="text-align:right"| 10 |width="20" style="text-align:right"| 12 |width="20" style="text-align:right"| 14 |width="20" style="text-align:right"| 16 |width="20" style="text-align:right"| 18 |width="20" style="text-align:right"| 20 |width="20" style="text-align:right"| 22 |width="20" style="text-align:right"| 24 |width="20" style="text-align:right"| 26 |width="20" style="text-align:right"| 28 |width="20" style="text-align:right"| 30 |- |style="background: #E0E0FF"| ''TORRO scale'' |style="background: #E0E0FF"| '''T''' |width="20" style="text-align:right"| 0 |width="20" style="text-align:right"| 1 |width="20" style="text-align:right"| 2 |width="20" style="text-align:right"| 3 |width="20" style="text-align:right"| 4 |width="20" style="text-align:right"| 5 |width="20" style="text-align:right"| 6 |width="20" style="text-align:right"| 7 |width="20" style="text-align:right"| 8 |width="20" style="text-align:right"| 9 |width="20" style="text-align:right"| 10 |width="20" style="text-align:right"| 11 |- |} The [[Beaufort scale]] was first introduced in 1805, and in 1921 quantified. It expresses the wind speed (v) by the formula: : [[Speed|v]] = 0.837 ''B''3/2 [[Metre per second|m/s]] == TORRO scale formula == Most UK tornadoes are T6 or below with the strongest known UK tornado being a T8. For comparison, the strongest detected winds in a United States tornado (during the [[1999 Oklahoma tornado outbreak]]) would be T11 using the following formulae: : ''[[Speed|v]]'' = 2.365 (''T''+4)3/2 [[Metre per second|m/s]] : ''[[Speed|v]]'' = 8.511 (''T''+4)3/2 [[Kilometres per hour|km/h]] : ''[[Speed|v]]'' = 5.289 (''T''+4)3/2 [[Miles per hour|mph]] : ''[[Speed|v]]'' = 4.596 (''T''+4)3/2 [[Knot (unit)|kn]] where ''v'' is [[wind speed]] and ''T'' is TORRO intensity number. Wind speed is defined as a 3-second gust at 10 [[metre|m]] [[Above ground level|AGL]]. Alternatively, the T-Scale formula may be expressed as: : [[Speed|v]] = 0.837 (2''T''+8)3/2 [[Metre per second|m/s]] or : [[Speed|v]] = 0.837(23/2) (''T''+4)3/2 [[Metre per second|m/s]] : or : T = (v/2.365) ^{2/3}-4 == Rating process and comparisons to Fujita scale == TORRO claims it differs from the [[Fujita scale]] in that it is "purely" a wind speed scale, whereas the Fujita scale relies on damage for classification, but in practice, damage is utilised almost exclusively in both systems to infer intensity. That is because such a proxy for intensity is usually all that is available, although users of both scales would prefer direct, objective, quantitative measurements. The scale is primarily used in the United Kingdom whereas the Fujita scale is the primary scale used in North America, continental Europe, and the rest of the world. At the 2004 European Conference on Severe Storms, Dr. Meaden proposed a unification of the TORRO and Fujita scales as the Tornado Force or TF Scale.{{cite web|last=Meaden |first=Terence |author2=TORRO members |title=Tornado Force or TF Scale |publisher=Tornado and Storm Research Organisation |year=2004 |url=http://www.torro.org.uk/TORRO/ECSS_Slide_Show/2004%20SPAIN%20ECSS%20Post-FINAL%20slide%20show.html |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100430211910/http://www.torro.org.uk/TORRO/ECSS_Slide_Show/2004%20SPAIN%20ECSS%20Post-FINAL%20slide%20show.html |archivedate=2010-04-30 |df= }} In 2007 in the United States, the [[Enhanced Fujita Scale]] replaced the original Fujita Scale from 1971.{{cite web|last=Grazulis |first=Tom |authorlink=Thomas P. Grazulis |title=The Fujita Scale of Tornado Intensity |publisher=The Tornado Project |year=1999 |url=http://www.tornadoproject.com/fscale/fscale.htm |accessdate=2011-12-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111230005516/http://www.tornadoproject.com/fscale/fscale.htm |archivedate=2011-12-30 |df= }} It made substantial improvements in standardizing damage descriptors through expanding and refining damage indicators and associated degrees of damage, as well as calibrated tornado wind speeds to better match the associated damage.{{cite web |last = Godfrey |first = Elaine |title = The Enhanced Fujita Tornado Scale |publisher = National Climatic Data Center |year = 2008 |url = http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/oa/satellite/satelliteseye/educational/fujita.html |accessdate = 2011-12-31 }} However, the EF Scale is biased to US construction practices.{{citation needed|date=December 2011}} As of 2014, only the United States and Canada have adopted the EF scale.{{cite web|title=Enhanced Fujita Scale (EF-Scale)|url=http://www.ec.gc.ca/meteo-weather/default.asp?lang=En&n=41E875DA-1|publisher=Environment Canada|accessdate=19 April 2014}}[http://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/storm_watch_stories3&stormfile=Measuring_tornadoes__F_vs._EF_scales_03_04_2012/ Measuring tornadoes: F-scale vs. EF-scale] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120409111640/http://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/storm_watch_stories3%26stormfile%3DMeasuring_tornadoes__F_vs._EF_scales_03_04_2012/ |date=April 9, 2012 }} Unlike with the F scale, no analyses have been undertaken at all to establish the veracity and accuracy of the T scale damage descriptors. The scale was written in the early 1970s, and does not take into account changes such as the growth in weight of vehicles or the great reduction in numbers and change of type of railway locomotives,{{citation needed|date=December 2011}} and was written in an environment where tornadoes of F2 or stronger are extremely rare, so little or no first-hand investigation of actual damage at the upper end of the scale was possible. The TORRO scale has more graduations than the F scale which makes it arguably more useful for tornadoes on the lower end of the scale{{citation needed|date=December 2011}}; however, such accuracy and precision are not typically attainable in practice. [[Harold E. Brooks|Brooks]] and [[Charles A. Doswell III|Doswell]] stated that "the problems associated with damage surveys and uncertainties associated with estimating wind speed from observed damage make highly precise assignments dubious".{{cite journal |last = Brooks |first = Harold |authorlink = Harold E. Brooks |author2=Charles A. Doswell III |title = Some aspects of the international climatology of tornadoes by damage classification |journal = Atmospheric Research |volume = 56 |issue = 1-4 |pages = 191–201 |publisher = |location = |year = 2001 |url = http://www.nssl.noaa.gov/users/brooks/public_html/toulclim.html |doi = 10.1016/S0169-8095(00)00098-3 |bibcode = 2001AtmRe..56..191B }} In survey reports, Fujita ratings sometimes also have extra qualifications added ("minimal F2" or "upper-end F3 damage"), made by investigators who have experience of many similar tornadoes and relating to the fact that the F scale is a damage scale, not a wind speed scale.{{citation needed|date=December 2011}} Tornadoes are rated after they have passed and have been examined, not whilst in progress. In rating the intensity of a tornado, both direct measurements and inferences from empirical observations of the effects of a tornado are used. Few [[anemometer]]s are struck by a tornado, and even fewer survive, so there are very few [[in-situ]] measurements. Therefore, almost all ratings are obtained from [[remote sensing]] techniques or as [[Proxy (climate)|proxies]] from damage surveys. [[Weather radar]] is used when available, and sometimes [[photogrammetry]] or [[videogrammetry]] estimates wind speed by measuring tracers in the vortex. In most cases, aerial and ground damage surveys of structures and vegetation are utilised, sometimes with engineering analysis. Also sometimes available are ground swirl patterns ([[cycloidal]] marks) left in the wake of a tornado. If an on site analysis is not possible, either for retrospective ratings or when personnel cannot reach a site, photographs, videos, or descriptions of damage may be utilised. == TORRO scale parameters == The 12 categories for the '''TORRO scale''' are listed below, in order of increasing intensity. Although the wind speeds and photographic damage examples are updated, which are more or less still accurate.{{cn|date=June 2016}} However, for the actual '''TORRO scale''' in practice, damage indicators (the type of structure which has been damaged) are predominantly used in determining the tornado intensity. {| class="wikitable" width="100%" |- style="text-align:center; background:gainsboro;" | rowspan="2" | '''Scale''' | colspan="3" | '''Wind speed'''
'''(Estimated)''' | rowspan="2" | '''Potential damage''' | rowspan="2" | '''Example of damage''' |- style="text-align:center; background:gainsboro;" || '''mph''' || '''km/h''' || '''m/s''' |- | align="center" bgcolor="#00FFFF" width=6% | '''FC''' | style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 0-38 || style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 0-60 || style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 0-16 |No damage. (Funnel cloud aloft, not a tornado) No damage to structures, unless on tops of tallest towers, or to radiosondes, balloons, and aircraft. No damage in the country, except possibly agitation to highest tree-tops and effect on birds and smoke. Record FC when not known to have reached ground level. A whistling or rushing sound aloft may be noticed. | |- | align="center" bgcolor="#B2FFFF" width=6% | '''T0''' | style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 39 - 54 || style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 61 - 86 || style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 17 - 24 |Light damage. Loose light litter raised from ground-level in spirals. Tents, marquees seriously disturbed; most exposed tiles, slates on roofs dislodged. Twigs snapped; trail visible through crops. | |- | align="center" bgcolor="#{{storm colour|storm}}" width=6% | '''T1''' | style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 55 - 72 || style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 87 - 115 || style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 25 - 32 |Mild damage. Deckchairs, small plants, heavy litter becomes airborne; minor damage to sheds. More serious dislodging of tiles, slates, chimney pots. Wooden fences flattened. Slight damage to hedges and trees. | |- | align="center" bgcolor="#00F189" width=6% | '''T2''' | style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 73 - 92 || style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 116 - 147 || style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 33 - 41 |Moderate damage. Heavy mobile homes displaced, light caravans blown over, garden sheds destroyed, garage roofs torn away, much damage to tiled roofs and chimney stacks. General damage to trees, some big branches twisted or snapped off, small trees uprooted. | |- | align="center" bgcolor="#DFF3DF" width=6% | '''T3''' | style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 93 - 114 || style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 148 - 184 || style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 42 - 51 |Strong damage. Mobile homes overturned / badly damaged; light caravans destroyed; garages and weak outbuildings destroyed; house roof timbers considerably exposed. Some of the bigger trees snapped or uprooted. | |- | align="center" bgcolor="#F7E98E" width=6% | '''T4''' | style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 115 - 136 || style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 185 - 220 || style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 52 - 61 |Severe damage. Motor cars levitated. Mobile homes airborne / destroyed; sheds airborne for considerable distances; entire roofs removed from some houses; roof timbers of stronger brick or stone houses completely exposed; gable ends torn away. Numerous trees uprooted or snapped. |[[File:2012-06-12 tornade Venise 1.JPG|150px]] |- | align="center" bgcolor="#{{storm colour|cat2}}" width=6% | '''T5''' | style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 137 - 160 || style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 221 - 259 || style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 62 - 72 |Intense damage. Heavy motor vehicles levitated; more serious building damage than for T4, yet house walls usually remaining; the oldest, weakest buildings may collapse completely. |[[File:Birmingham tornado 2005 damage.jpg|150px]] |- | align="center" bgcolor="#E9D66B" width=6% | '''T6''' | style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 161 - 186 || style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 260 - 299 || style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 73 - 83 |Moderately - devastating damage. Strongly built houses lose entire roofs and perhaps also a wall; windows broken on skyscrapers, more of the less-strong buildings collapse. |[[File:August 2008 tornado in Poland - Kalina p2.jpg|150px]] |- | align="center" bgcolor="#{{storm colour|cat3}}" width=6% | '''T7''' | style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 187 - 212 || style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 300 - 342 || style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 84 - 95 |Strongly - devastating damage. Wooden-frame houses wholly demolished; some walls of stone or brick houses beaten down or collapse; skyscrapers twisted; steel-framed warehouse-type constructions may buckle slightly. Locomotives thrown over. Noticeable debarking of trees by flying debris. | |- | align="center" bgcolor="#E49B0F" width=6% | '''T8''' | style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 213 - 240 || style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 343 - 385 || style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 96 - 107 |Severely - devastating damage. Motor cars hurled great distances. Wooden-framed houses and their contents dispersed over long distances; stone or brick houses irreparably damaged; skyscrapers badly twisted and may show a visible lean to one side; shallowly anchored high rises may be toppled; other [[steel-framed buildings]] buckled. ([[2008 Poland tornado outbreak]], for example) | |- | align="center" bgcolor="#{{storm colour|cat4}}" width=6% | '''T9''' | style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 241 - 269 || style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 386 - 432 || style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 108 - 120 |Intensely - devastating damage. Many steel-framed buildings badly damaged; skyscrapers toppled; locomotives or trains hurled some distances. Complete debarking of any standing tree-trunks. | |- | align="center" bgcolor="#FE5A1D" width=6% | '''T10''' | style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 270 - 299 || style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 433 - 482 || style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| 121 - 134 |Super damage. Entire frame houses and similar buildings lifted bodily or completely from foundations and carried a long or large distance to disintegrate. Steel-reinforced concrete buildings may be severely damaged or almost obliterated. | |- | align="center" bgcolor="#{{storm colour|cat5}}" width=6% | '''T11''' | style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| >300 || style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| >483 || style="text-align:center; width:8%;"| >135 |Phenomenal damage. Strong framed, well built houses leveled off foundations and swept away. Steel-reinforced concrete structures are critically damaged. Tall buildings collapse or have severe structural deformations. Some cars, trucks and train cars can be thrown approximately 1 mile (1.6 kilometres). | |- |} {| class="wikitable" width="100%" |- | T0 || T1 || T2 || T3 || T4 || T5 || T6 || T7 || T8 || T9 || T10 || T11 |- | colspan=4 align="center" style="background: #fd0;" | Weak | colspan=4 align="center" style="background: #f3943f;" | Strong | colspan=4 align="center" style="background: #ff6060;" | Violent |- |} == See also == * [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale]] * [[Tornado intensity and damage]] * [[Wind engineering]] * [[List of tornadoes and tornado outbreaks]] == References == {{reflist|2}} * {{cite book |last = Grazulis |first = Thomas P. |authorlink = Thomas P. Grazulis |title = Significant Tornadoes 1680-1991, A Chronology and Analysis of Events |publisher = The Tornado Project of Environmental Films |year = 1993 |location = St. Johnsbury, VT |url = |isbn = 1-879362-03-1 }} * {{cite journal |last = Meaden |first = G. T. |authorlink = |title = Tornadoes in Britain: Their intensities and distribution in space and time |journal = [[Journal of Meteorology]] |volume = 1 |issue = 8 |pages = 242–51 |publisher = |location = UK |year = 1976 |url = |doi = }} * {{cite journal |last = Meaden |first = G. T. |authorlink = |title = A study of tornadoes in Britain, with assessments of the general tornado risk potential and the specific risk potential at particular regional sites |journal = [[Journal of Meteorology]] |volume = 8 |issue = 79 |pages = 151–3 |publisher = |location = UK |year = 1985 |url = |doi = }} == External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051109225809/http://www.torro.org.uk/TORRO/severeweather/tscale.php TORRO Tornado Intensity Scale] (TORRO) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120205020044/http://www.torro.org.uk/TORRO/severeweather/Tscaleorigin.php T-Scale Origins and Scientific Basis] (TORRO) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100430211910/http://www.torro.org.uk/TORRO/ECSS_Slide_Show/2004%20SPAIN%20ECSS%20Post-FINAL%20slide%20show.html Wind speed scales: Beaufort, T Scale, and Fujita's Scale] (TORRO) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060117120112/http://www.tordach.org/topics/intensity_en.htm Determination of tornado or downburst intensity] (TorDACH) [[Category:Hazard scales]] [[Category:Wind]] [[Category:Tornado]]

{{Use Australian English|date=December 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2013}} {{Infobox Australian place | type = suburb | name = Tamala Park | city = Perth | state = wa | image = | caption = | lga = City of Wanneroo | alternative_location_map = Australia Western Australia metropolitan Perth | coordinates = {{coord|31.709|S|115.724|E|display=inline,title}} | area = 4.2 | postcode = 6030 | pop = 0 | pop_year = {{CensusAU|2011}} | pop_footnotes = {{Census 2011 AUS| id= SSC50753 |name= Tamala Park (State Suburb)| accessdate=17 February 2017|quick=on}} | stategov = [[Electoral district of Mindarie|Mindarie]] | fedgov = [[Division of Pearce|Pearce]] | est = 1988 | near-nw = | near-n = [[Mindarie, Western Australia|Mindarie]]
[[Clarkson, Western Australia|Clarkson]] | near-ne = [[Neerabup, Western Australia|Neerabup]] | near-w = ''[[Indian Ocean]]'' | near-e = [[Neerabup, Western Australia|Neerabup]] | near-sw = | near-s = [[Burns Beach, Western Australia|Burns Beach]]
[[Kinross, Western Australia|Kinross]] | near-se = [[Neerabup, Western Australia|Neerabup]] | dist1 = 31 | dir1 = NNW | location1= [[Perth (suburb)|Perth CBD]] }} '''Tamala Park''' is an unpopulated locality in [[Perth]], [[Western Australia]]. It sits on the border between the [[City of Wanneroo]] and the [[City of Joondalup]] local authorities, and separates the [[Clarkson, Western Australia|Clarkson]]-[[Butler, Western Australia|Butler]] region from the suburbs of Joondalup. == History == The [[Mooro]] group of [[Noongar]] were familiar with the area, and several of their traditional stories and legends refer to local Tamala Park land features, such as [[Wagyl|Waukolup]] Hill, although evidence suggests that they lived much further east, closer to modern-day [[Wanneroo Road]].{{cite web|url=http://trails.heritage.wa.gov.au/ht_pdf/YaberooBudjara.pdf|format=PDF|title=Yaberoo Budjara Heritage Trail|author=Heritage Council of WA|date=June 1998|accessdate=2007-01-17|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060820011810/http://trails.heritage.wa.gov.au/ht_pdf/YaberooBudjara.pdf|archivedate=20 August 2006|df=dmy-all}} The suburb was formally established by excision of parts of [[Mindarie, Western Australia|Mindarie]], [[Clarkson, Western Australia|Clarkson]] and [[Burns Beach, Western Australia|Burns Beach]] on 9 September 1988.{{Gazette WA|title=Naming and Change of Name of Localities. City of Wanneroo|date=9 September 1988|page=1988:3497|file=1421/983}} == Present use == At present, Tamala Park is mostly unoccupied [[bushland]], primarily used as a [[landfill]] and [[recycling]] centre. Two arterial roads, [[Marmion Avenue]] and [[Connolly Drive]], run through it and link the suburbs on each side. It is a large locality, extending from the [[Joondalup railway line]] in the east, to the coast of the Indian Ocean, where it leads onto [[Burns Beach, Western Australia|Burns Beach]] to the south and Claytons Beach in Mindarie to the north. Tamala Park is in the process of being developed. The Tamala Park Regional Council (TPRC) was established to develop {{convert|165|ha}} of land in the Tamala Park locality. The Council comprises 12 councillors representing the 7 owner councils that make up the TPRC as follows: * [[Town of Cambridge]] * [[City of Joondalup]] * [[City of Perth]] * [[City of Stirling]] * [[City of Wanneroo]] * [[Town of Victoria Park]] * [[City of Vincent]] Tamala Park is the 10th regional and 154th local government council to be established by proclamation in the Government Gazette in February 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.tamalapark.wa.gov.au|title=Tamala Park Regional Council}}{{Gazette WA|title=Local Government Act 1995: Establishment of a Regional Council|date=3 February 2006|page=2006:535}} == References == {{Reflist}} {{City of Wanneroo suburbs}} [[Category:Suburbs of Perth, Western Australia]] {{PerthAU-geo-stub}} {{Waste-stub}}

revision.text:
{{chembox | ImageFile=Me4N+.png | ImageSize= | ImageFile1=Tetramethylammonium-cation-3D-balls.png | ImageSize1=225px | PIN = ''N'',''N'',''N''-Trimethylmethanaminium{{cite book | title = Nomenclature of Organic Chemistry : IUPAC Recommendations and Preferred Names 2013 (Blue Book) | publisher = [[Royal Society of Chemistry|The Royal Society of Chemistry]] | date = 2014 | location = Cambridge | page = 1086 | doi = 10.1039/9781849733069-FP001 | isbn = 978-0-85404-182-4}} | OtherNames=Tetramethylammonium
Tetramethylazanium
Tetramine |Section1={{Chembox Identifiers | ChemSpiderID_Ref = {{chemspidercite|correct|chemspider}} | ChemSpiderID = 6140 | InChI = 1S/C4H12N/c1-5(2,3)4/h1-4H3/q+1 | InChIKey = QEMXHQIAXOOASZ-UHFFFAOYSA-N | StdInChI_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChI = | StdInChIKey_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChIKey = | CASNo= 51-92-3 | ChEMBL= | PubChem=6380 | ChEBI_Ref = {{ebicite|correct|EBI}} | ChEBI = 46020 | SMILES = C[N+](C)(C)C }} |Section2={{Chembox Properties | Formula=C4H12N+ | MolarMass=74.14 g/mol | Appearance= | Density= | MeltingPt= | BoilingPt= | Solubility= }} |Section3={{Chembox Hazards | MainHazards= | FlashPt= | AutoignitionPt = }} }} '''Tetramethylammonium''' ('''TMA''') or ('''Me4N+''') is the simplest [[quaternary ammonium cation]], consisting of four [[methyl group]]s attached to a central [[nitrogen]] atom, and is [[isoelectronic]] with [[neopentane]]. It is positively charged and can only be isolated in association with a [[counter-ion]]. Common [[quaternary ammonium salt|salts]] include [[tetramethylammonium chloride]] and [[tetramethylammonium hydroxide]]. Tetramethylammonium salts are used in chemical synthesis and are widely employed in pharmacological research. ==Common nomenclature== In the toxicological literature, ''naturally occurring'' tetramethylammonium (anion unspecified) is often referred to by the name "tetramine". Unfortunately, this non-systematic or "trivial" name is also used for other chemical entities, including a toxic rodenticide ([[Tetramethylenedisulfotetramine]]). Similarly, the acronym "TMA", which is frequently used for tetramethylammonium in the pharmacological literature, may also refer to the investigational drug [[3,4,5-trimethoxyamphetamine]], which, being a close structural analog of [[mescaline]], has been the subject of numerous publications. ==Occurrence== TMA has been detected in or isolated from a number of marine organisms, mostly amongst the [[Cnidaria]] and [[Mollusca]], notably in some species of ''[[Neptunea]]'' (commonly called [[whelks]]) that are eaten by humans.{{cite journal | last1 = Anthoni | first1 = U. | last2 = Bohlin | first2 = L. | last3 = Larsen | first3 = C. | last4 = Nielsen | first4 = P. | last5 = Nielsen | first5 = N. H. | last6 = Christophersen | first6 = C. | year = 1989 | title = Tetramine: Occurrence in marine organisms and pharmacology | url = | journal = Toxicon | volume = 27 | issue = | pages = 707–716 | doi=10.1016/0041-0101(89)90037-8}}{{cite journal | last1 = Dolan | first1 = L. C. | last2 = Matulka | first2 = R. A. | last3 = Burdock | first3 = G. A. | year = 2010 | title = Naturally occurring food toxins | journal = Toxins (Basel) | volume = 2 | issue = | pages = 2289–2332 | pmc=3153292 | pmid=22069686 | doi=10.3390/toxins2092289}} It has also been found in one plant, the African ''[[Courbonia virgata]]'' (Cappariaceae).{{cite journal | last1 = Henry | first1 = A. J. | year = 1948 | title = The toxic principle of ''Courbonia virgata'': its isolation and identification as a tetramethylammonium salt | journal = Br. J. Pharmacol. Chemother. | volume = 3 | issue = | pages = 187–188 | pmc=1509833 | pmid=18883998 | doi=10.1111/j.1476-5381.1948.tb00373.x}} ==Preparation, reactions, solution properties== One of the most straightforward methods of preparing a simple salt containing the tetramethylammonium ion is by the reaction between [[trimethylamine]] and a [[alkyl halide|methyl halide]]: :Me3N + Me−I → Me4N+I− [14C]-labeled TMA has been made by this method.{{cite journal | last1 = Tsubaki | first1 = H. | last2 = Nakajima | first2 = E. | last3 = Komai | first3 = T. | last4 = Shindo | first4 = H. | year = 1986 | title = The relation between structure and distribution of quaternary ammonium ions in mice and rats. Simple tetraalkylammonium and a series of m-substituted trimethylphenylammonium ions | url = | journal = J. Pharmacobio-Dyn. | volume = 9 | issue = | pages = 737–746 | doi=10.1248/bpb1978.9.737}} Although this reaction is suitable for the common halides, tetramethylammonium salts with more complex anions may be prepared by [[salt metathesis]] reactions, e.g. [[tetramethylammonium borohydride]] has been made from [[tetramethylammonium hydroxide]] as shown:{{cite journal | last1 = Banus | first1 = M. D. | last2 = Bragdon | first2 = R. W. | last3 = Gibb | first3 = T. R. P. | year = 1952 | title = Preparation of quaternary ammonium borohydrides from sodium and lithium borohydrides | url = | journal = J. Am. Chem. Soc. | volume = 74 | issue = | pages = 2346–2348 | doi=10.1021/ja01129a048}} Me4N+[OH]− + Na+[BH4]− → Me4N+[BH4]− + Na+ + HO− Although TMA salts do possess some of the [[phase-transfer catalyst|phase-transfer catalytic]] properties that are characteristic of [[quaternary ammonium compounds]], they tend to behave atypically because of the relatively high ''[[hydrophilicity]]'' of the TMA cation.{{cite journal | last1 = Fedorynski | first1 = M. | last2 = Ziolkowska | first2 = W. | last3 = Jonczyk | first3 = A. | year = 1993 | title = Tetramethylammonium salts: highly selective catalysts for the preparation of gem-dichlorocyclopropanes from electrophilic alkenes and chloroform under phase-transfer catalysis conditions | url = | journal = J. Org. Chem. | volume = 58 | issue = | pages = 6120–6121 | doi=10.1021/jo00074a047}} TMA cation is [[hydrophilic]].{{cite journal | last1 = Koga | first1 = Y. | last2 = Westh | first2 = P. | last3 = Nishikawa | first3 = K. | last4 = Subramanian | first4 = S. | year = 2011 | title = Is a methyl group always hydrophobic? Hydrophilicity of trimethylamine-N-oxide, tetramethyl urea and tetramethylammonium ion | url = | journal = J. Phys. Chem. B | volume = 115 | issue = | pages = 2995–3002 | doi=10.1021/jp108347b}} The [[partition coefficient]] of TMA iodide in octanol-water, ''P''o-w, is {{val|1.2e-4}} (or {{nowrap|log ''P'' ≈ −3.92}}). In the TMA cation, the methyl groups are tetrahedrally arranged around the central N atom, as is evident from X-ray crystallographic studies of various of its salts.{{cite journal | last1 = McLean | first1 = W. J. | last2 = Jeffrey | first2 = G. A. | year = 1967 | title = Crystal structure of tetramethylammonium fluoride tetrahydrate | url = | journal = J. Chem. Phys. | volume = 47 | issue = | pages = 414–417 | doi=10.1063/1.1711910}}{{cite journal | last1 = McCullough | first1 = J. D. | year = 1964 | title = The crystal structure of tetramethylammonium perchlorate | url = | journal = Acta Crystallogr | volume = 17 | issue = | pages = 1067–1070 | doi=10.1107/s0365110x64002687}} From measurements taken on molecular models, it has been estimated that the diameter of the TMA ion is ~0.6 nm;{{cite journal | last1 = McCleskey | first1 = E. W. | last2 = Almers | first2 = W. | year = 1985 | title = The Ca channel in skeletal muscle is a large pore | url = | journal = Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA | volume = 82 | issue = | pages = 7149–7153 | doi=10.1073/pnas.82.20.7149| pmc = 391328 }} From more accurate physico-chemical measurements, the [[ionic radius]] for TMA is given as 0.322 nm; several thermodynamic parameters for the TMA ion are also recorded.{{cite journal | last1 = Aue | first1 = D. H. | last2 = Webb | first2 = H. M. | last3 = Bowers | first3 = M. T. | year = 1976 | title = A thermodynamic analysis of solvation effects on the basicities of alkylamines. An electrostatic analysis of substituent effects | url = | journal = J. Am. Chem. Soc. | volume = 98 | issue = | pages = 318–329 | doi=10.1021/ja00418a002}}{{cite journal | last1 = Palomo | first1 = J. | last2 = Pintauro | first2 = P. N. | year = 2003 | title = Competitive absorption of quaternary ammonium and alkali metal cations into a Nafion cation-exchange membrane | url = | journal = J. Membrane Sci. | volume = 215 | issue = | pages = 103–114 | doi=10.1016/s0376-7388(02)00606-3}} The paper by Aue et al. gives a good discussion of the methods by which the ionic radius was determined. ==Pharmacology== The pharmacological literature on tetramethylammonium is extensive.Over 1300 citations in PubMed, as of October 2012. In general, TMA is a [[cholinomimetic]] whose effects mimic most of those produced by exogenous [[acetylcholine]].''Drill's Pharmacology in Medicine, 4th Ed.'' (1971), J. R. DiPalma, Ed., p. McGraw-Hill, NJ. Pharmacological experiments with TMA have been performed using one of its salts, typically the chloride, bromide or iodide, since these anions were not expected to interfere with the actions of the TMA cation. In the early pharmacological literature, however, there are references to the use of "[[tetramethylammonium hydroxide]]" or "tetramethylammonium hydrate", which were meant to facilitate comparison between weight-based dosages of different TMA salts,{{cite journal | last1 = Burn | first1 = J. H. | last2 = Dale | first2 = H. H. | year = 1915 | title = The action of certain quaternary ammonium bases | url = | journal = J. Pharmacol. Exp. Ther. | volume = 6 | issue = | pages = 417–438 }} but did not involve the actual use of tetramethylammonium hydroxide, whose strong basicity would have been incompatible with physiological conditions. A thorough review of the pharmacology of TMA from a toxicological perspective, and current up to 1989, has been given by Anthoni and co-workers. Thus, the effects of TMA on [[nicotinic]] and [[muscarinic]] [[ACh receptor]]s first stimulate, then block neurotransmission in sympathetic and parasympathetic ganglia, with [[depolarization]]. TMA also acts as an [[agonist]] at muscarinic receptors in post-ganglionic nerve endings in [[smooth muscle]]s, cardiac muscle, and [[exocrine]] glands. In [[skeletal muscle]], TMA initially causes [[fasciculation]]s, then paralysis, as a result of the depolarization from stimulation of nicotinic ACh receptors. ===Absorption; distribution; metabolism; excretion (ADME)=== Absorption: TMA is readily absorbed from the gastro-intestinal tract. Studies on the rat [[jejunum]] indicated that TMA absorption involved a combination of simple diffusion and carrier-mediated transport, with nearly 100% absorption occurring within 60 to 90 minutes. By comparison, [[tetraethylammonium]] and tetrapropylammonium ions were only absorbed to the extent of ~30%.{{cite journal | last1 = Tsubaki | first1 = H. | last2 = Komai | first2 = T. | year = 1986 | title = Intestinal absorption of tetramethylammonium and its derivatives in rats | url = | journal = J. Pharmacobio-Dyn. | volume = 9 | issue = | pages = 747–754 | doi=10.1248/bpb1978.9.747}} Distribution: [[Intraperitoneal]] administration of radio-labeled tetramethylammonium iodide to mice showed that TMA was rapidly distributed to all parts of the body, with the highest concentrations being in the kidney and liver. Similar results were reported by Neef and co-workers using rats.{{cite journal | last1 = Neef | first1 = C. | last2 = Oosting | first2 = R. | last3 = Meijer | first3 = D. K. F | year = 1984 | title = Structure-pharmacokinetics relationship of quaternary ammonium compounds | url = | journal = Naunyn-Schmiedebergs Arch. Pharmakol. | volume = 328 | issue = | pages = 103–110 | doi=10.1007/bf00512058}} Metabolism and excretion: Parenteral administration of radio-labeled tetramethylammonium iodide to rats resulted in almost the whole dose being excreted in urine, without any evidence of metabolic transformation. ==Toxicology== The human toxicology of TMA (under the name "tetramine" has been studied primarily in the context of accidental poisoning after ingestion of ''Neptunea'' species. Symptoms include the following: nausea, vomiting, headache, vertigo/dizziness, impaired vision/temporary blindness, [[diplopia]], [[photophobia]], lack of balance, feeling of intoxication and [[urticaria]]. These symptoms appear within 30 minutes but recovery is usually complete after a few hours. Only one account of human death following ingestion of TMA (from the plant ''Courbonia virgata'') has been recorded. Although many of these symptoms can be accounted for on the basis of impairment of neurotransmission in the [[autonomic nervous system]], there also seem to be distinct indications of central affects. In animal studies, parenteral administration of TMA-containing extracts from ''Neptunea'' to mice, cats and fish mainly show effects involving skeletal muscles: there are muscular [[fasciculation]]s, convulsions, loss of balance, motor paralysis and ultimately cessation of respiration. The lethal oral dose of TMA for humans has been estimated at 3–4 mg/kg. The lethal dose for rats was estimated to be ~45–50 mg/kg, p.o., and ~15 mg/kg, i.p.{{cite journal | last1 = Anthoni | first1 = U. | last2 = Bohlin | first2 = L. | last3 = Larsen | first3 = C. | last4 = Nielsen | first4 = P. | last5 = Nielsen | first5 = N. H. | last6 = Christophersen | first6 = C. | year = 1989 | title = The toxin tetramine from the "edible" whelk ''Neptunea antiqua'' | url = | journal = Toxicon | volume = 27 | issue = | pages = 717–723 | doi=10.1016/0041-0101(89)90038-x}} ===Acute toxicity=== LD50 for TMA chloride: 25 mg/kg (mouse, i.p.); 40 mg/kg (mouse, s.c.). LC50 for TMA chloride: 462 mg/L for 96 hrs. (Fathead minnow, ''Pimephales promelas''). R. J. Lewis (Ed.) (2004), ''Sax's Dangerous Properties of Industrial Materials, 11th Ed.'' p. 3409, Wiley-Interscience, Wiley & Sons, Inc., Hoboken, NJ.http://toxnet.nlm.nih.gov/cgi-bin/sis/search/a?dbs+hsdb:@term+@DOCNO+7987 ==See also== * [[Tetraethylammonium]] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Quaternary ammonium compounds]] [[Category:Cations]]
